abstract: On Mandela Day, people around the world will be urged to volunteer, much as they are on countless other occasions.
snippet: On Mandela Day, people around the world will be urged to volunteer, much as they are on countless other occasions.
lead_paragraph: THERE was a time when holidays meant a break from working. Not so anymore, as seemingly every day of the year is National Something-or-Other Day. And a handful of nonprofits, with help from the White House, are working to rebrand occasions like Martin Luther King’s Birthday and Sept. 11 as national days of volunteering, to say nothing of César Chávez Day (March 31), Make a Difference Day (the fourth Saturday of October), National Volunteer Week (the third week of April) and Be the Change Day (this year, Oct. 3). Add one more to the calendar: Mandela Day, July 18, when people around the world will be urged to perform 67 minutes of community service to honor the 67 years (and counting) that Nelson Mandela has fought for racial and social equality. The holiday is the brainchild of the Nelson Mandela Foundation and 46664, the advocate group that bears Mr. Mandela’s prisoner number.

headline.main: How to Stand Out on One More Day Aimed at Volunteers
headline.print_headline: How to Stand Out On One More Day Aimed at Volunteers

abstract: The broader financial crisis certainly precipitated the demise of America’s largest carmaker, but it was not the ultimate cause.

lead_paragraph: What drove General Motors into bankruptcy? It’s tempting to blame the broader financial crisis, which torpedoed the United States economy, dragged down car sales and shut carmakers out of the capital markets. That overriding factor certainly precipitated the demise of America’s largest carmaker, but it was not the ultimate cause.

abstract: The F.D.I.C. postponed a central piece of the U.S. bank rescue plan indefinitely, acknowledging that it could not persuade enough banks to sell off their bad assets.

lead_paragraph: Borrowing by American consumers dropped by the second-biggest amount on record in April. Consumer credit fell $15.7 billion, or 7.4 percent at an annual rate, to $2.52 trillion, according to a Federal Reserve report released in Washington. Credit decreased by a record $16.6 billion in March, more than previously estimated. Spending by consumers declined for a second consecutive month in April.

headline.main: Consumer Credit Fell $15.7 Billion in April

abstract: A government agency calculated that 41,800 jobs were lost in May, more than the 36,000 bank analysts anticipated in a consensus forecast.
snippet: A government agency calculated that 41,800 jobs were lost in May, more than the 36,000 bank analysts anticipated in a consensus forecast.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s unemployment rate rose by 0.4 percentage point in May to reach 8.4 percent, an 11-year high. The government agency calculated that 41,800 jobs were lost during the month, more than the 36,000 bank analysts anticipated in a consensus forecast. Not surprisingly, the biggest losses came in Ontario, home to the country’s auto industry. The poor employment news came amid anxiety over the 12 percent increase in the value of the Canadian dollar against its American counterpart over the last month. On Thursday the Bank of Canada warned that the rapid rise in the Canadian dollar might stifle Canada’s economic recovery if it continued.

headline.main: Canada’s Jobless Rate Is 8.4%, an 11-Year High
headline.print_headline: Canada’s Jobless Rate Is 8.4%,. An 11-Year High

abstract: The company will pay a $2.3 million civil penalty in an agreement with the Consumer Product Safety Commission for selling toys with hazardous levels of lead.
snippet: The company will pay a $2.3 million civil penalty in an agreement with the Consumer Product Safety Commission for selling toys with hazardous levels of lead.
lead_paragraph: Mattel and its Fisher-Price subsidiary have agreed to pay a $2.3 million civil penalty in an agreement with the Consumer Product Safety Commission for selling toys with hazardous levels of lead. Mattel recalled more than 21 million toys made in China, including some Elmo and Dora the Explorer toys, after they were found in 2007 to have lead paint or dangerous designs. After the recalls by Mattel and other companies in 2007, Congress overhauled consumer regulations, effectively banning lead in toys, requiring the C.P.S.C. to hire more workers and increasing fines on sellers of dangerous products.

headline.main: Mattel to Pay $2.3. Million Penalty for Lead in Toys
headline.print_headline: Mattel To Pay $2.3. Million Penalty For Lead In Toys

lead_paragraph: Shares in Jackson Hewitt Tax Service, the country’s second-biggest tax-preparation company after H & R Block, rose the most in almost five years after naming Harry Buckley as chief executive to run the company while it seeks “strategic alternatives.” Mr. Buckley, a former chief executive officer of H&R Block’s tax-preparation unit, replaces Michael C. Yerington, who was ousted. The company also hired the Goldman Sachs Group to look at a range of possibilities, according to a statement, using language that typically means a company might be sold. Jackson Hewitt has been losing customers to H & R Block and Intuit, which makes TurboTax software. Shares closed at $6.25, up 45 percent.

headline.main: In a Shake-Up, Jackson Hewitt Names a New Chief

abstract: A tribute to Peter Bernstein, a firm believer in the efficient market theory, and a great guy just to talk to.
snippet: A tribute to Peter Bernstein, a firm believer in the efficient market theory, and a great guy just to talk to.
lead_paragraph: I read in The Times this morning, to my surprise, that Peter L. Bernstein had died. True, he was 90 years old, but he had been active, engaged — and working — until a few days ago, when he broke his hip and then died of pneumonia in the hospital. Mr. Bernstein was perhaps best known for two books he wrote at a stage in life when most people are retired: “Against The Gods: The Remarkable Story of Risk,” and “Capital Ideas: The Improbable Origins of Modern Wall Street.” As my colleague Louis Uchitelle noted in his affectionate obituary, Mr. Bernstein was a firm believer in the efficient market theory — the subject of my column last Saturday — and especially the power of diversification, which he touted constantly. He founded The Journal of Portfolio Theory. Harry Markowitz, who was awarded a Nobel Prize, for, essentially, creating portfolio theory, was one of his heroes. Mr. Bernstein’s last book, “Capital Ideas Evolving,” published two years ago, was an attempt (more successful than not) at incorporating some of the ideas of behavioral finance into the broader efficient market theory championed by the likes of Mr. Markowitz and Eugene Fama of the University of Chicago.

headline.main: Peter Bernstein’s Capital Ideas

lead_paragraph: The members of the Boston Newspaper Guild voted narrowly on Monday — 277 to 265 — to reject a package of pay and compensation cuts at The Boston Globe that the paper’s owner, The New York Times Company, insisted were necessary to guarantee the paper’s survival. Shortly after the vote results were announced, the company made good on its threat to impose a 23 percent pay cut unilaterally, saying it would take effect next week.

lead_paragraph: Calling itself “a daily online magazine of Jewish news, ideas, and culture,” Tablet magazine began publishing Tuesday. The Web site is a project of the nonprofit Nextbook Inc. and the sister organization of Nextbook Press, which publishes a line of Jewish-themed books. Tablet lists an impressive bunch of contributors and is edited by Alana Newhouse, the former culture editor of The Forward, along with Jesse Oxfeld, who has worked at New York magazine and Gawker and serves as executive editor.

It doesn’t hurt, of course, that his brother happens to be Rahm Emanuel, President Obama’s chief of staff. But this has left everyone else in Hollywood wondering just what Mr. Emanuel wants and how he will use his power to shape the entertainment industry of the 21st century.

headline.main: Ari Emanuel Is Hollywood’s New Big Man on Campus, But What Is He After?

snippet: Initial jobless claims continue to fall.
lead_paragraph: Some economists expressed healthy skepticism about last week’s Labor Department report showing that the pace of job losses had eased sharply in May. Some of the slowdown was a result of a statistical adjustment that the department makes, and such adjustments can turn out to be fleeting. The report was also based on a survey that was done before the General Motors bankruptcy plan — which calls for more than 20,000 job cuts — was announced.

headline.main: More Reason for (Guarded) Hope on Jobs

abstract: A Bond Reprieve.
snippet: A Bond Reprieve.
lead_paragraph: The United States Treasury bond market has been feeling distinctly unloved. A 10-year bond auction went badly on June 10 after Russia, Brazil and China said they were taking steps to diversify their foreign currency reserves. Worries that the $11 billion auction of 30-year bonds on Thursday would follow suit rattled the market. But central banks flocked to buy the bonds, meaning dollar diversification fears were overblown for now.

headline.main: For the Treasury, a Reprieve in the Bond Market

It was from Simon Maziarz of Jupiter, Fla., who runs MyMudSpace, and it is best appreciated in full:

abstract: Ping An Insurance Company plans to buy a $3.2 billion stake in the Shenzhen Development Bank Company.
snippet: Ping An Insurance Company plans to buy a $3.2 billion stake in the Shenzhen Development Bank Company.
lead_paragraph: Ping An Insurance Company, shifting its focus to the Chinese market after losing $3.3 billion on an investment in the European insurer Fortis, plans to buy a 22 billion renminbi ($3.2 billion) stake in the Shenzhen Development Bank Company. Ping An, a major insurer in China, agreed to purchase as many as 585 million new shares from Shenzhen Development for 10.7 billion renminbi, the company said. Ping An will also buy 520.4 million Shenzhen shares from Newbridge Capital, the Asian unit of TPG Inc., for about 11.45 billion renminbi. The stake of Ping An, which already owns 4.7 percent of the Chinese bank, may rise to as much as 34 percent after the transactions. The deal would extend a push by Peter Ma, Ping An’s chairman, to build a financial supermarket, while helping Shenzhen Development plug a capital shortfall.

headline.main: Chinese Insurer Increases Stake in Bank
headline.print_headline: Chinese Insurer Increases Stake In Bank

lead_paragraph: The Hartford Financial Services Group said it would accept as much as $3.4 billion in federal Troubled Asset Relief Program funds and sell $750 million of shares. The stock fell 8 percent, to $12.95. The common share offering to private investors will be carried out over time in a so-called discretionary equity issuance, Hartford said in a statement. Last month the Treasury Department approved six insurance companies for TARP money, but only Hartford has accepted so far. It has posted about $12.4 billion in write-downs and unrealized losses tied to the collapse of the subprime mortgage market, second-worst among American insurers to the American International Group.

headline.main: Hartford Financial to Sell Stock and Take TARP Money

lead_paragraph: Bombardier is reducing its 10-year industry forecast for business jet deliveries by nearly 15 percent from last year because of the global recession. The company says it now expects there will be 11,500 business jets delivered by the industry from 2009 to 2018. Waning demand for business planes has forced manufacturers to lay off thousands of employees as they reduce production. Bombardier has announced that 4,360 employees will be laid off in Canada, the United States and Northern Ireland.

headline.main: Canada: Bombardier Cuts Business Jet Forecast

abstract: India’s national carrier will defer salary payments for its 31,000 employees by two weeks because of a cash squeeze born of tepid demand and overcapacity, the company says.
snippet: India’s national carrier will defer salary payments for its 31,000 employees by two weeks because of a cash squeeze born of tepid demand and overcapacity, the company says.
lead_paragraph: Air India, India’s national carrier, will defer salary payments for its 31,000 employees by two weeks because of a cash squeeze born of tepid demand and overcapacity, the company says. “We are in a low-fare regime. The fuel tax is going up. The number of passengers is not that high. There is excess capacity in the market,” Jitender Bhargava, an Air India spokesman, said. He said the carrier, which is entirely owned by the government of India, lost about 40 billion rupees ($800 million) in the fiscal year ended March 31 and would pay 3.5 billion rupees ($70 million) in June salaries on July 15 instead of July 1. Domestic air travel in India fell by 15 percent in April from the same month a year ago, the 11th consecutive monthly decline, according to the Center for Asia Pacific Aviation.

headline.main: India: Air India to Delay Paying 31,000 Workers
headline.print_headline: India: Air India to Delay Paying 31,000 Workers

abstract: Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries was ordered to sell natural gas to a company owned by his younger brother, Anil, for 44 percent less than the government-set price, lawyers said.

lead_paragraph: Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries, India’s most valuable company, was ordered to sell natural gas to a company owned by his younger brother, Anil, for 44 percent less than the government-set price, lawyers said. The high court in Mumbai, formerly Bombay, ruled the company had to honor a 2005 agreement to supply 28 million cubic meters of gas a day at $2.34 for each million British thermal units for 17 years, said Mukul Rohatgi, counsel for Anil Ambani’s Reliance Natural Resources. Reliance Industries will decide on its “future course of action based on legal advice,” it said in an e-mailed message.

headline.main: India: Verdict Favors Anil Ambani Over Brother

abstract: Keeping an eye on the politics and policies that can make or break small businesses.
snippet: Keeping an eye on the politics and policies that can make or break small businesses.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s just me, but it does seem, now more than ever, as if every other utterance from our elected officials contains the phrase “small business,” or one of its variants. These officials constantly remind us that the country’s prosperity hinges on the success of its small businesses and entrepreneurs — that is, on you. And, of course, your prosperity depends in no small amount on what’s decided — and what’s not decided — in Washington and in places like Albany, Sacramento and Des Moines.

abstract: The Boston Globe’s largest union has set a date for a contract ratification vote, though there is no agreement on a contract.
snippet: The Boston Globe’s largest union has set a date for a contract ratification vote, though there is no agreement on a contract.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Globe’s largest union has set a date for a contract ratification vote, though there is no agreement on a contract. The Boston Newspaper Guild sent a memo to members late Thursday, telling them that it had scheduled a vote for July 20. The guild and The Globe are still negotiating on a package of pay and benefit cuts, with face-to-face talks set to resume Monday, and people briefed on the discussions say a deal is close.  But in the meantime, The Globe’s owner, The New York Times Company, is insisting that a 23 percent pay cut is in effect for Guild members. The company unilaterally imposed the cut after guild members narrowly rejected a previous package of concessions, including a 10.3 percent salary reduction and deep cuts in benefits. The guild has challenged the unilateral cut with a complaint to the federal regulators, but that could take years to resolve. Guild bylaws require a 30-day wait before a contract proposal is voted on, and the 23 percent cut — which will show up in paychecks sent out next week — gives the union an incentive to start that clock ticking as soon as possible. So betting on the chance that the two sides will strike a deal early next week, the guild set a date for a vote. People briefed on the talks say negotiators have the outlines of a deal similar to the one that was rejected, but with a smaller pay cut in the range of 7 or 8 percent. The major stumbling block, they say, is dealing with the 23 percent cut, which would have been in effect for more than a month. The guild wants to find a way to repay some or all of that money to its members.

headline.main: Globe Update: Union Sets Contract Vote

lead_paragraph: Nokia Siemens Networks agreed to pay $650 million for the wireless unit of the bankrupt phone-equipment maker Nortel Networks Corporation. At least 2,500 employees will be offered the chance to move to Nokia Siemens, Nortel said. The company said it was also in talks to sell other businesses and was applying to have its shares delisted from the Toronto Stock Exchange. Nortel filed for bankruptcy protection in January after posting losses of almost $7 billion over two years.

abstract: A crossword celebration of exit lines.
snippet: A crossword celebration of exit lines.
lead_paragraph: It seems to be a hot trend. The current Atlantic Magazine has a wonderful poem on page 82 by William Heyen called Heaven, which starts with Henry Thoreau’s last words (“Moose … Indian”) and Joe DiMaggio’s (“I’ll finally get to see Marilyn”). Today’s crossword by Matt Ginsberg and Pete Muller collects a dozen more deathbed quotes and asks us to identify the speakers. Call me morbid but I love this puzzle, mostly because the exit lines are all clever or funny or curiously (sometimes sadly) appropriate. I’m feeling some pressure now to come up with something good myself for when I expire. Maybe it’s not me but Mr. Ginsberg who’s the morbid one. Do you remember his controversial “Parting Thoughts” from last summer? (Across Lite, Solution)

lead_paragraph: You can’t tell much from the box office performance of a film on a single night, in a single foreign country. But Paramount executives were congratulating themselves on Saturday over the Friday night results of “Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen,” in Britain. Word had it that the movie had done roughly 50 percent better than its predecessor, which two years ago went on to take in $389 million in foreign markets, and $319 at the domestic box office.

It can be an intransitive verb (meaning to joke) or a transitive verb (to make fun of) or a noun (a joke). Remember jape because it shows up about once a year in New York Times puzzles. Of course, on Mondays you can always get it from crosses, right? But is 5 Down ICE DAM or ICE JAM? See, you need to remember that other word, I jape you not.

Pandit, has spent months stitching together a turnaround plan, yet he has been dogged by mess after mess since he started. Some federal regulators question whether he is up for the task. abstract: You might have thought it would be a smooth ride to passage for such an amendment. Small businesses are practically sacred on Capitol Hill, and they are facing higher interest rates and much lower credit limits on their company cards. So what happened, and why?
snippet: You might have thought it would be a smooth ride to passage for such an amendment. Small businesses are practically sacred on Capitol Hill, and they are facing higher interest rates and much lower credit limits on their company cards. So what happ...
lead_paragraph: Often, when legislation dies on the Senate floor, you know who did it in. But when Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana and chairman of the Senate Small Business Committee, tried, and failed, to get new consumer credit card protections extended to small businesses last month, the perpetrator — or perpetrators — left no fingerprints. In fact, there’s no agreement on what precisely happened, or why. The Congressional Record is ambiguous. And no senator, Democratic or Republican, has explained on the record why small businesses were left behind when the Credit Cardholders’ Bill of Rights Act of 2009 became law on May 22.

headline.main: Who Killed Small-Business Credit Card Protection?

abstract: You can adjust the audio levels for your Web browser, system sounds, instant-message program, games and other sound-producing programs.
snippet: You can adjust the audio levels for your Web browser, system sounds, instant-message program, games and other sound-producing programs.
lead_paragraph: Want to have more control over the sounds coming out of your Windows Vista system? Start by clicking the volume icon in the Vista taskbar, which pops up a single volume slider. Ignore the slider, but click on the link for Mixer underneath it. This brings up the Volume Mixer, which has individual volume sliders for each multimedia program running at the moment. By moving the separate sliders, you can adjust the audio levels for your Web browser, system sounds, instant-message program, games and other sound-producing programs. Click the speaker button under each slider to quickly mute a program  which can be handy if you want to watch a DVD or play a game and temporarily turn off all the other noise on your machine.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Controlling Sounds From Vista

abstract: The Lloyds Banking Group plans to cut 270 jobs at its insurance and offshore operations, bringing to more than 4,450 the number of positions the bank has eliminated since April. The bank will eliminate jobs at its Channel Islands unit and its insurance division in Clevedon, western England, the bank said in a statement. Lloyds said it planned to create 70 posts in risk management, mostly in Edinburgh. The company has pledged to lower costs after the acquisition of HBOS in January created a bank with more than 3,000 branches and a 28 percent share of Britain’s mortgage market. Lloyds, now 43 percent government-owned, is seeking to save more than £1.5 billion ($2.5 billion) by 2011.

abstract: Satyam Computer Services named Chander Prakash Gurnani, below, as its chief executive in the aftermath of an accounting scandal. Satyam, an outsourcing firm, has been bought by Tech Mahindra, which is working to reorganize the company. Mr. Gurnani, formerly Tech Mahindra’s head of international operations, replaces A. S. Murty, Satyam said in a statement. Subramaniam Durgashankar, formerly senior vice president for mergers and acquisitions at Mahindra & Mahindra, was appointed chief financial officer. Mr. Gurnani, 50, is in charge of reviving Satyam after a stock collapse prompted by an admission by its former chairman, B. Ramalinga Raju, that he overstated assets by more than $1 billion. Mr. Gurnani pledged to improve corporate governance and customer ties. A reorganization of the company will be announced within 48 hours, he said.

A.I.G., which is seeking to repay loans within a government bailout valued at $182.5 billion, has disclosed deals raising about $6.7 billion. AIG Universal, which has 50 branches in central and northern Mexico, sells insurance and extends personal loans to about 50,000 customers.

lead_paragraph: Tax cuts from the stimulus package and increases in Social Security checks lifted personal incomes sharply in May, the government reported on Friday, but it appeared that many people were putting that money away instead of spending it.

headline.main: U.S. Savings Rate at Highest Point in 15 Years
headline.print_headline: As Incomes Rebound, Saving Hits Highest Rate in 15 Years

abstract: The agency has gently loosened lending restrictions for one of its loan programs. But it’s not clear this will stimulate any new lending.
snippet: The agency has gently loosened lending restrictions for one of its loan programs. But it’s not clear this will stimulate any new lending.
lead_paragraph: The Small Business Administration has once more turned to its stimulus-supplied toolbox in the effort to open up the blocked spigot of capital. (That’s the S.B.A.’s toolbox metaphor, not The Agenda’s. We’ve simply extended it.) On Wednesday the agency gently loosened lending restrictions (pdf) for its underrated 504 loan program. The new policy aims to improve a small company’s cash flow by restructuring existing debt — but only if that firm borrows new money to expand. What’s unclear is how many firms are brave enough in this economy to take the government up on the offer.

headline.main: From the S.B.A., Another Small Step

abstract: With the deaths of Michael Jackson and Farrah Fawcett on Thursday, TV networks turned over most of prime time to specials remembering the pop icons. CBS’s special garnered the most viewers.
snippet: With the deaths of Michael Jackson and Farrah Fawcett on Thursday, TV networks turned over most of prime time to specials remembering the pop icons. CBS’s special garnered the most viewers.
lead_paragraph: With the deaths of Michael Jackson and Farrah Fawcett on Thursday, the major television networks turned over most of prime time to news specials remembering the pop icons. CBS’s “Life and Death of Michael Jackson” garnered the most viewers of the three network specials honoring the singer, drawing 7.6 million at 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. That compared with 5.7 million for ABC’s “20/20” special about Jackson an hour earlier at 9 and 5.5 million for NBC’s two-hour “Dateline” special, which looked back at the lives of both celebrities from 9 to 11.

headline.main: Thursday Ratings: Large Audiences for CBS’s Jackson Special, Fawcett Program on ABC

lead_paragraph: TMZ, the carnivorous celebrity news Web site, is accustomed to beating other media outlets on the stories that shape the entertainment world. On Thursday, it not only scooped every other outlet by announcing Michael Jackson’s death, it apparently beat the coroner’s office, too  by six minutes.

headline.main: TMZ Was Far Ahead in Reporting Death
headline.print_headline: A Web Site Scooped Other Media On the News

abstract: KB Home, the Los Angeles-based home builder that caters to first-time buyers, fell 9.1 percent after reporting a wider quarterly loss than analysts expected.
snippet: KB Home, the Los Angeles-based home builder that caters to first-time buyers, fell 9.1 percent after reporting a wider quarterly loss than analysts expected.
lead_paragraph: KB Home, the Los Angeles-based home builder that caters to first-time buyers, fell 9.1 percent after reporting a wider quarterly loss than analysts expected. The net loss for the three months that ended May 31 was $78.4 million, or $1.03 a share, compared with analysts’ estimates of a 63-cent loss, according to a Bloomberg survey. A year earlier, the company reported a net loss of $255.9 million, or $3.30 a share. KB Home is slashing prices and reducing the size of its houses to compete with foreclosed houses for sale. Foreclosure filings, including default and auction notices as well as property seizures, climbed 18 percent in May from a year earlier, according to RealtyTrac.

headline.main: Competing Against Foreclosures, KB Home Posts Loss
headline.print_headline: Competing Against Foreclosures, KB Home Posts Loss

abstract: Cisco Systems, Alcatel-Lucent and other companies do not have to follow “buy American” rules for some computer components supplied under a $4.7 billion program to build high-speed Internet lines.
snippet: Cisco Systems, Alcatel-Lucent and other companies do not have to follow “buy American” rules for some computer components supplied under a $4.7 billion program to build high-speed Internet lines.
lead_paragraph: Cisco Systems, Alcatel-Lucent and other companies do not have to follow “buy American” rules for some computer components supplied under a $4.7 billion program to build high-speed Internet lines, a federal agency ruled. The domestic-sourcing rule is waived for equipment used in tasks including broadband switching and routing, according to a notice from the Commerce Department’s National Telecommunications and Information Administration. The rules aimed at protecting American jobs must be followed for fiber lines, coaxial cables and wireless telecommunications towers.

headline.main: ‘Buy American’ Waiver for Computer Components
headline.kicker: Business Briefing | Court and Regulatory Action
headline.print_headline: ‘Buy American’ Waiver For Computer Components

abstract: Palm, maker of the new Pre smartphone, had its best day in five months in Nasdaq trading after reporting a smaller loss than analysts had estimated and spending less cash.
snippet: Palm, maker of the new Pre smartphone, had its best day in five months in Nasdaq trading after reporting a smaller loss than analysts had estimated and spending less cash.
lead_paragraph: Palm, maker of the new Pre smartphone, had its best day in five months in Nasdaq trading after reporting a smaller loss than analysts had estimated and spending less cash. Palm said it had cash and equivalents of $255.1 million as of May 29, the end of its fourth quarter. The company spent $72.4 million in cash in the period, less than the $92.1 million in the previous quarter. The company plans to start generating cash in the second half of this fiscal year, bolstered by the Pre and its new WebOS operating system. Palm introduced the Pre on June 6, challenging Apple’s iPhone and Research in Motion’s BlackBerry.

headline.main: Palm’s Smaller Loss Pushes Share Price Up
headline.print_headline: Palm’s Smaller Loss Pushes Share Price Up

abstract: JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup are expanding their “jumbo” mortgage businesses used to buy the most expensive homes.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup are expanding their “jumbo” mortgage businesses used to buy the most expensive homes.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup are expanding their “jumbo” mortgage businesses used to buy the most expensive homes, helping revive a market that shriveled amid a three-year jump in homeowner defaults. JPMorgan resumed buying new jumbo loans made by other lenders this month, after halting purchases in March, a spokesman said. Citigroup is again offering the loans through independent mortgage brokers, a spokesman said. The two New York-based banks are signaling new interest in a market hobbled since 2007, when record-breaking defaults on home loans caused investors to flee securities backed by mortgages.

headline.main: Two Banks Re-enter the Jumbo Mortgage Business
headline.print_headline: Two Banks Re-enter the Jumbo Mortgage Business

abstract: “Transformers” sequel blasts out of the starting gate.
snippet: “Transformers” sequel blasts out of the starting gate.
lead_paragraph: Despite horrendous reviews, Michael Bay’s “Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen” roared out of the blocks last week with a huge five-day opening of $201.2 million — just a hair shy of the $203.8 million earned by Christopher Nolan’s “Dark Knight” last summer. It proved, once again, the stubborn power of sequels to draw Americans to the multiplex, especially those sequels that promise to replicate the original rather than striking out in unfamiliar directions. In short, it’s not the venal Hollywood executives who keep insisting on shoveling the same thing at audiences time and time again, as critics often charge — it’s audiences that insist upon it.

headline.main: Optimus Prime Indeed: ‘Transformers’ Sequel Roars Out of the Gates

lead_paragraph: Edward Snyder, a cellphone industry analyst with Charter Equity Research, often plays the role of cautious pessimist.
